The actions of discipline are of three kinds, namely, those included in the discipline of individual liberation, those included in the discipline of meditation, and those included in the undefiled discipline.

As for the actions included in the discipline of individual liberation, they are the disciplines accepted by the seven assemblies, namely, the discipline of bhiká¹£us, the discipline of bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, the discipline of Å›iká¹£aá¹‡amÄá¹‡as, the discipline of Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras, the discipline of Å›rÄmaá¹‡erÄ«s, the discipline of upÄsakas, the discipline of upÄsikÄs, and the discipline of upavÄsa practitioners.
Based on what kind of person is the discipline of going forth established?
Based on those who are able to practice the avoidance of evil conduct and the avoidance of sexual conduct.

Because only the five groups of renunciant bhiká¹£us and so forth are able to completely abandon evil conduct such as killing for their entire lives, and are able to completely abandon sexual misconduct.
Based on what kind of pudgala is the upÄsaka and upÄsikÄ precepts established?
Based on those who are able to completely abandon evil conduct for their entire lives, but not abandon sexual conduct.
Because those two groups establish the precepts of abandoning sexual misconduct for their entire lives, but not abandoning sexual conduct.
Based on what kind of pudgala is the one-day precepts established?
Based on those who are unable to completely abandon evil conduct, and also unable to abandon sexual conduct.
Therefore, for them only the one-day precepts are established, in order to gradually cause them to study and practice both.
Question:
If one only studies and practices one part of the upÄsaka precepts, is it said that one accomplishes the upÄsaka precepts?
Or is it said that one does not accomplish them?
Answer:
It should be said that one accomplishes them, but is called one who violates the precepts.
Question:
Are eunuchs, hermaphrodites, and so on, prohibited from receiving the precepts of an upÄsaka?
Answer:

They are not prohibited from receiving the precepts of an upÄsaka, but they are prohibited from the status of an upÄsaka, because they are unable to closely attend and serve the two monastic communities of monks and nuns.
Just as eunuchs and hermaphrodites are unable to closely attend and serve the two monastic communities of monks and nuns, they are prohibited from the status of an upÄsaka.

The same is true for those with two sexual organs. Because the afflictions of both men and women always occur simultaneously in them, they are unable to closely attend and serve the two communities, so it is not specifically mentioned.
Moreover, there are five types of hermaphrodites: those who are born as hermaphrodites, jealous hermaphrodites, half-month hermaphrodites, sprinkling hermaphrodites, and removed hermaphrodites.
As for the karma included in the precepts of meditative concentration, it refers to that which can subdue and eliminate the seeds of afflictions that give rise to transgressions of precepts.
The separation from the desire realm and the separation from the desires of the first, second, and third dhyanas are called the nature of bodily and verbal actions included in the precepts of dhyana.
The afflictions that give rise to transgressions refer to the afflictions and secondary afflictions of the desire realm, such as greed and hatred.
The seeds that are suppressed refer to the seeds that are suppressed by the power of the antidotes.
Those who are separated from the desires of the desire realm refer to those who, by the power of the antidotes, are either partially or completely separated from desire.
The separation refers to the nature of separation obtained from them.

Those who are separated from the desires of the first, second, and third dhyanas refer to those who, by the power of the antidote of complete separation, cause the seeds of the afflictions that give rise to transgressions to be further damaged.
The reason for not speaking of separation from the desires of the fourth dhyana is that because the formless realm lacks coarse form, the precepts of form are not established in brief.
The karma included in the pure precepts refers to the nature of the pure precepts of non-transgression obtained by those who have seen the truth through the power of pure attention.
The karma of non-restraint refers to the definite performance of that karma by those who are unrestrained, either by being born in that class or by undertaking that occupation.
What are called those who are unrestrained?

They are butchers of sheep, poultry keepers, pig farmers, birdcatchers, fishermen, hunters, trappers, robbers, executioners, cattle butchers, elephant tamers, those who set up altars to curse dragons, jailers, slanderers, and those who delight in harming others.
Butchers of sheep kill sheep for a living, buying and selling them.
In the same way, poultry keepers, pig farmers, and so on, according to their respective occupations.
Elephant tamers always stay in the mountains and forests, taming wild elephants.
Those who set up altars to curse dragons study the spells of dragons and snakes, amusing themselves and making a living.
Those who live by slander and intrigue are those who make a living by destroying the intimacy of others through divisive speech.
Either by being born in that class or by undertaking that activity refers to those who are born in that very family or in another family, respectively.

The definite performance of the action that is intended refers to the definite performance of the action that is intended after the preliminary performance of the action by means of body and speech. This is called the action of the unvirtuous restraints.

The action that is neither virtuous nor nonvirtuous refers to the virtuous and nonvirtuous actions of those who are neither restrained nor unrestrained. It is called neither virtuous nor nonvirtuous because it is not included in the virtuous or nonvirtuous restraints.
Moreover, action is classified into three types: action that produces pleasant feeling, action that produces unpleasant feeling, and action that produces neither pleasant nor unpleasant feeling.
Action that produces pleasant feeling refers to the virtuous action from the desire realm up to the third meditative absorption.
Karma that produces suffering is unwholesome karma.
Karma that produces neither-suffering-nor-happiness is wholesome karma in the fourth meditation and above.
Next, karma is divided into three types: karma that produces results in the present life, karma that produces results in the next life, and karma that produces results in subsequent lives.
Karma that produces results in the present life means that if karma produces results in the present life, it is called karma that produces results in the present life.
For example, if one creates harm or benefit towards someone after emerging from the meditation of loving-kindness, one will definitely obtain results in the present life.

Just as after emerging from the meditation of loving-kindness, after emerging from the meditation of no-conflict, the meditation of cessation, the fruit of stream-entry, or the fruit of arhatship, it is the same.
Moreover, if one creates wholesome or unwholesome karma towards the Sangha headed by the Buddha, one will definitely obtain results in the present life.
Furthermore, if one creates wholesome or unwholesome karma with a strong intention and skillful means, one will also obtain results in the present life.
The reason it is called karma that produces results in the present life is because if karma is created in this life, it will mature in this life.
As for karma to be experienced in the next life, if karma ripens in the next life without interruption,
without interruption means immediately after this life.
It refers to the five heinous acts, etc., which can obtain the ripening of rebirth.
Question:
If one commits one heinous act, one can experience its ripening in the next life without interruption;
if one commits many heinous acts, how can one experience their ripening in the next life without interruption?
Answer:
There is no fault in experiencing all the obtained ripening all at once in one life.
Why is this?

If one commits many heinous acts, the body one receives is extremely delicate, and the painful objects one experiences are numerous and intense. For this reason, one experiences various great sufferings all at once.
Moreover, there is other good and bad karma that ripens in the next life without interruption. All of this is called karma to be experienced in the next life.
As for karma to be experienced later, if karma ripens in the life after next without interruption,
In this action, from the initial stage of ripening, the names of karma to be experienced in the present life, etc. are established, and it is not only experienced in this stage of ripening.

If an action is created in this life, and from this life on, the ripening matures, it is called karma to be experienced in the present life.ğŸ”½If an action is created in this life, and from the next life on, the ripening matures, it is called karma to be experienced in the next life.
If an action is created in this life, and after passing the next life, the ripening matures, it is called karma to be experienced in a later life.
If this is said, it is well in accord with the Sutra of the Mind of Hatred.
As that sutra says:
Due to uninterrupted karma, one is repeatedly born and dies in the hells, and experiences the great suffering of ripening.

Next, there are four kinds of distinctions in karma, namely black karma with black ripening, white karma with white ripening, black-and-white karma with black-and-white ripening, and neither black nor white karma without ripening that can exhaust all karma.
Black-black ripening karma refers to unwholesome karma, because it is defiled and has unlovely ripening.
White-white ripening karma refers to wholesome karma in the three realms, because it is undefiled and has lovely ripening.
Black-white black-white ripening karma refers to mixed karma in the desire realm, because it is a mixture of wholesome and unwholesome.
How can one karma be both wholesome and unwholesome?

Here, one kind of karma is not said to be both wholesome and unwholesome in terms of the characteristics of the moment of arising, but rather in terms of intention and means is one karma said to be so. This is the meaning of this sutra.
In terms of these two, if black and white are mutually dissimilar, one kind of black-white karma is established.ğŸ”½There is karma that is black because of intention but white because of means.
There is karma that is black because of means but white because of intention.

The fourth is black in intention and white in means, like the case of someone who, in order to deceive others, first manifests his appearance and, in order to gain their trust, practices generosity and even goes forth.

The fifth is white in means and black in intention, like the case of someone who, in order to lead his children and disciples away from danger to safety, out of a compassionate mind manifests various kinds of coarse physical and verbal actions, and as a result at that time generates defiled, neither black nor white, non-retribution karma.

The sixth is karma that can exhaust all karma, which refers to all pure karma in the path of preparation and the uninterrupted path, because the path of preparation and the uninterrupted path are the antidotes that eliminate those various karmas.
It is not black because it is free from the defilements of afflictions.
It is white because it is completely pure.
It has no retribution because it is contrary to birth and death.
Karma that can exhaust all karma is so called because by the power of pure karma, the three impure karmas of black, etc., and their habitual tendencies of retribution are forever eliminated.

Furthermore, in general, all uncontaminated actions are established as crooked, defiled, turbid, etc., and pure, sage, etc., according to their respective natures of obstruction and conformity, without distinction.
Crooked action refers to bodily, verbal, and mental actions that obstruct the arising and growth of the eightfold noble path of uprightness.
Defiled action refers to bodily, etc., actions that defile the continuum, based on which such obstructive actions arise.

Turbid action refers to bodily, etc., actions that arise based on the inverted views of non-Buddhists, which are to be counteracted by the pure holy teachings of all TathÄgatas, because they are included in disbelief and turbidity.
There is another distinction: falling to the extremes of annihilation and permanence, contradicting the meaning of practicing the middle way, is called crooked.
Included in the diminishing views, increasing evil and defiling the established meaning of purity, is called defiled.
Included in the view of the aggregates, obstructing the meaning of seeing the true non-self, is called turbid.
Pure action is understood as the opposite of such defiled actions.
The third kind of pure action refers to the pure precepts.
It is included in the correct view, because it is bodily, verbal, and mental action that is far removed from the defilements of transgressions and wrong views.
The third kind of action of the Muni refers to the impure bodily, verbal, and mental actions of those in training and beyond training, because only the Muni has this kind of action.
There is also the pure action of giving, etc.
What is the action of giving?
It is the action of giving distinguished according to cause, origination, location, and essence.
The cause refers to the roots of goodness of non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion.
Origination refers to the volition that accompanies them.
The location refers to the objects that are given.
The essence refers to the bodily, verbal, and mental actions at the time of practicing giving.
What is the perfection of giving?
That is to say, because of giving repeatedly, because of giving without partiality, and because of giving in accordance with the desires and fulfilling them, giving is perfected.
Based on this meaning, the sÅ«tra says this.
Being a great donor shows the meaning of giving repeatedly, because by repeatedly cultivating it becomes one's nature and one is able to give repeatedly.
All Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, etc. shows the meaning of giving without partiality, because one gives to all without discrimination.
Food, drink, etc. shows the meaning of giving in accordance with desires and fulfilling them, because one gives all wealth as one wishes.

Furthermore, because of giving without relying on anything, because of giving that is widely pure, because of giving with utmost joy, because of giving repeatedly, because of giving to worthy recipients, and because of distributing new and old gifts well, giving is perfected.
Based on this meaning, the sÅ«tra says this:

Liberation, equanimity, stretching out the hand to give, delighting in separation, always performing sacrifices, abandoning completely, and being content to distribute equally at the time of proper giving.
These phrases show in order giving without dependence and so forth.
Giving without dependence means giving without turning to existence and wealth.
The field means the field of poverty and suffering, and the field of merit.
Stretching out the hand means widely practicing giving, with the hand not shrinking back.
Always performing sacrifices means habitually performing sacrifices to form one's nature.
Abandoning completely means wisdom comes first.
Being content to distribute equally at the time of proper giving means distributing equally the given objects to those who come seeking.
How should one know the perfection of the given object?

That is to say, the property given is not obtained through deception or fraud, the property given is not obtained by harming others, the property given is not defiled and free from impurities, the property given is pure, and the property given is properly acquired. This is called the perfection of the property given.
Based on this meaning, the sÅ«tra says:

The property obtained through initiating right effort - this shows that the property given is not obtained through deception or fraud. That which is obtained through deception or fraud refers to obtaining property without initiating right effort, because one deceives and fraudulently obtains property entrusted by others in one's own residence.
The property obtained through the power of one's own arms - this shows that the property given is not obtained by harming others.
That which is obtained by harming others is not obtained through one's own exertion.
Because one takes by force the property obtained by others through various means and efforts.
The property free from impurities - this shows that the property given is not defiled and free from impurities, because the property given is far removed from defiled impurities.
In accordance with the Dharma means that the given objects are pure, far removed from impure objects such as weapons, poisons, and alcohol.

Obtained in accordance with the Dharma means that the given objects are obtained in accordance with the Dharma, far removed from wealth obtained through wrong livelihood such as deceptive weights and measures.
Moreover, as it is said in the sutra:

One who has accomplished the precepts is able to well protect the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts, and is perfect in both deportment and practice. Seeing even the subtlest offenses, one gives rise to great fear, and is able to well accept and practice the precepts.
What does it mean to have accomplished the precepts?
It means being able to accept and protect pure precepts.
That is to say, one upholds pure precepts without deficiency, and is therefore said to have accomplished the precepts.
What does it mean to be able to well protect the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts?
It means being able to well protect the precepts that lead to liberation.

That is to say, for the sake of seeking liberation, one separately protects all the precepts, and is therefore called the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts. This is because by these precepts one is able to quickly escape from the suffering of birth and death.
How is it that their conduct in accordance with the precepts is completely fulfilled?
Because they possess pure precepts and are difficult to criticize.
Those whose conduct is fulfilled have deportment and so forth that are not criticized by wise people.
Those whose practice is fulfilled are far removed from the five kinds of places that should not be frequented by bhiká¹£us.
What are the five?
Namely, the homes of town criers, prostitutes, liquor sellers, kings, and caá¹‡á¸Älas.
How is it that they see even the subtlest offenses as extremely frightening?
Because they are vigorous and respectful in learning the precepts.

They are vigorous and respectful in learning and upholding even the proscribed offenses as if they were natural offenses. Therefore, it is said that they see even the subtlest offenses as extremely frightening.
How is it that they are well able to accept and learn the precepts?
Because they completely accept and learn the precepts.
It means that they completely accept and learn the precepts. Therefore, it is said that they are well able to accept and learn the precepts.
From this point on, based on morality, he explains the meaning of protecting the body and so forth in the Buddha's sutras.
What is meant by guarding the body and speech?
Because they are upheld by right understanding.
That is to say, one must first be aware of the matters of coming and going as permitted by the Buddha before practicing them correctly.
What is meant by the perfection of body and speech?
Because one never violates what should not be violated.
That is to say, one does not go against pure morality.
What is meant by the pure practice of body and speech?
Because one gradually practices without regret and so forth, and eventually attains concentration as a support.
That is to say, because one relies on the power of concentration to completely distance oneself from the defilements of violating precepts.
What is meant by the extremely good practice of body and speech?
Because it is not mixed with defiled discursive thoughts.
That is to say, it is not able to be mixed with defiled discursive thoughts, because it is exclusively pure.
What is meant by the practice of body and speech that is free from offenses?
Because one practices pure conduct while distancing oneself from wrong aspirations.
That is, one does not dedicate oneself to existence and material wealth, but practices pure conduct praised by the sages and saints.
What is meant by the performance of non-harming in body and speech?
Not slighting others and being easy to live with.
That is, not harming others by being self-important and difficult to live with.
What is meant by the performance of conformity in body and speech?
Because it leads to the attainment of nirvana.
That is, because it leads to the attainment of nirvana and can induce the noble path.
What is meant by the performance of concealment and revelation in body and speech?
Concealing goodness and revealing evil.
That is, concealing one's own merits and revealing one's own faults.
What is meant by the performance of friendliness in body and speech?ğŸ”½Because one who practices the same pure conduct accepts the precepts.
That is, because one who practices the same pure conduct accepts the precepts and should take refuge.
What is meant by the performance of propriety in body and speech?
Because one is free from arrogance towards the venerable and their position.
That is, one subdues arrogance in the presence of superiors and equals, as befits the occasion, in order to serve them.
How does one practice bodily and verbal respect?
Because one respectfully accepts the teachings of superiors.
That is, one respectfully accepts the words of superiors, free from the grasping of one's own views.
How does one practice bodily and verbal freedom from distress?
Because one is far removed from the distress of ascetic practices and inferior aspirations.
That is, one is free from the ascetic practices and inferior aspirations of non-Buddhists, because one does not burn oneself.
How does one practice bodily and verbal non-affliction?
Because one gives up wealth and work without regret.
That is, because one gives up wealth and work without regret, one has no distress later.
How does one practice bodily and verbal non-remorse?
Because one is not remorseful even when obtaining a small amount.
That is, although one cultivates wholesome practices and obtains a small amount, one does not give rise to satisfaction, free from all remorse, because one practices to the utmost of one's ability.
As the World-Honored One said:

Thus, all sentient beings are all due to their own karma, are in conflict due to karma, are born from karma, are liberated based on karma, and karma can distinguish the high, low, superior, and inferior of all sentient beings.
How are sentient beings all due to their own karma?
Because one experiences the ripening of karma created by oneself.
That is to say, because all sentient beings are due to their own karma, they are called due to their own karma.
The self does not share with others, and experiences the ripening of one's own karma, thus it is called one's own karma.
How are they in conflict due to karma?
Because when experiencing the ripening obtained from one's own karma, good and bad karma mutually conflict.
That is to say, because sentient beings are in conflict due to karma, they are called in conflict due to karma.
Because one experiences the ripening of good and bad karma according to oneself, with distinctions between what is loved and not loved.
Question:
When all sentient beings experience the ripening of their own karma, whether loved or not, from what do they initially arise?
Are they without a cause?
Are they caused by karma, time, nature, or a supreme being, etc.?
Answer:
They are born from karma.
How are they born from karma?
Because all sentient beings are born only from karma, free from causelessness and bad causes.
That is to say, all sentient beings, free from causelessness and bad causes, are born only from causes and conditions such as karma.

Thus, it has been explained how samsara occurs based on karma. In order to clarify the return to cessation, it is also based on karma. Therefore, the sutra says: based on karma, one attains liberation.
How does one attain liberation based on karma?
Because one relies on counteractive karma to liberate oneself from the bondage of karma.
That is to say, because one relies on pure karma to eliminate impure karma, one attains liberation only based on karma.
How are sentient beings high or low?
It is because of karma that one obtains the differences in one's body in good or evil destinies.
How are they superior or inferior?
It is because sentient beings accomplish the differences in merits and faults.
As the World-Honored One said:
The ripening of karma of sentient beings is inconceivable.
The meaning of this sÅ«tra is not that all kinds are inconceivable.
How is the ripening of karma inconceivable?
How is it conceivable?
It is conceivable that good karma leads to rebirth in the human and heavenly realms and to obtaining pleasant ripening,
and that evil karma leads to rebirth in the three evil destinies and to obtaining unpleasant ripening.
This is because worldly sages can conceive of this, and because it can give rise to the merits of right view and so forth.
However, the various distinctions in the ripening of one's own body and so forth that are brought about by this karma are inconceivable.

This is because the ripening of one's own body and so forth has countless distinctions such as having form and so on that are difficult to conceive, and except for omniscience, one cannot conceive of them. If one forcefully tries to conceive of them, one will go mad and so forth.

Furthermore, the distinctions in the realms of good and bad karma, the distinctions in events, the distinctions in causes, the distinctions in karmic retribution, and the distinctions in categories, etc., are all inconceivable.
This is because the distinctions in the realms of karma, etc., are immeasurable and boundless, and difficult to conceive.
Realm refers to abiding in such a realm and creating such karma.
Either in a city or a village, and so forth.
Event refers to the basis, which may be sentient or non-sentient.
Cause refers to the roots of good and evil, as appropriate.
Retribution refers to the internal body that is ripened.
Category refers to the various distinctions and immeasurable categories.
There are also various distinctions in external events that can produce inconceivable karmic effects.
By what karma are thorns and other sharp and pointed things produced? Such things fall into the category of the inconceivable in the world.
Because it is the world of the conceivable, it is prohibited by the Buddha.
Moreover, the functions of karma associated with wish-fulfilling gems, medicinal herbs, and spells are inconceivable.
As for karma associated with wish-fulfilling gems, it refers to the difficult-to-conceive functions of karma such as the moon-loving pearl being able to produce water, etc.
As for karma associated with medicinal herbs, it refers to the ability to hide one's form by holding onto certain herbs.
As for karma associated with spells, it refers to the ability to avoid being burned by reciting certain spells.
As for karma associated with techniques, it refers to the ability to cure fevers, etc. by means of various techniques.
Moreover, the functions of the power of practitioners of meditation are inconceivable.
How so?
By the power of their minds, they are able to shake the great earth, ascend into the sky, and so forth.

Moreover, the autonomous activities of the bodhisattvas are inconceivable, namely, because of the autonomy of life, the autonomy of mind, the autonomy of wealth, the autonomy of karma, the autonomy of birth, the autonomy of resolve, the autonomy of vows, the autonomy of spiritual powers, the autonomy of wisdom, and the autonomy of the Dharma.
Because of these autonomous powers, the activities of the great bodhisattvas are inconceivable.
That is to say, the bodhisattvas, by the power of the autonomy of life, maintain their life-force and abide for as long as they wish.
By the power of the autonomy of mind, they freely enter and exit samÄdhi according to their wishes.
By the power of the autonomy of resolve, they transform the great earth and so forth into water, fire, and so forth, with autonomous resolve.
By the power of the autonomy of vows, they are able to draw forth innumerable great vows for their own benefit and the benefit of others, according to their wishes.
By the power of freely controlling spiritual powers, in order to attract and transform immeasurable sentient beings, they manifest various spiritual transformations.
By the power of freely controlling wisdom, they explain the meaning of the Dharma without obstruction, and their eloquence is perfect and ultimate.

By the power of freely controlling the Dharma, they establish the unsurpassed teachings such as the sutras with immeasurable kinds of names, phrases, and sentences, and according to their needs, they are able to cause the minds of all sentient beings to greatly rejoice at one time.
Moreover, all the things that Buddhas should do and the deeds that Buddhas should perform are inconceivable.
How so?
The TathÄgata has reached the stage of effortless perfection and realized the pure, single-flavored Dharma realm.
The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, are able to accomplish the things that should be done to benefit and bring peace to sentient beings at the appropriate times.
In this way, the Buddhas and the Buddha-realm are inconceivable.

Furthermore, this truth of origination is generally of four kinds of characteristics, namely, the characteristic of cause, the characteristic of accumulation, the characteristic of birth, and the characteristic of condition.
What is the characteristic of cause?

It is the cause of the perfuming of subsequent existence that is able to attract. This is called the characteristic of cause, because karma and afflictions are the cause of the perfuming of subsequent existence that is able to attract.
What is the characteristic of accumulation?
It is the perfuming accumulated by each sentient being that is the cause of arising in each class of sentient beings. This is called the characteristic of accumulation.
Because the perfuming accumulated by sentient beings is able to be the cause of the arising of similar forms and types in the class of sentient beings such as humans and gods.
What is the characteristic of birth?
It is the cause of the birth of innumerable kinds of distinctions in each individual body. This is called the characteristic of birth.
Because it is the cause of the birth of all kinds of distinctions in the individual bodies and continuous destinies of sentient beings up to the peak of existence.
What is the characteristic of condition?
The causes of sentient beings' individual attainment and abandonment are called the characteristics of conditions.
It causes sentient beings to attain a self-nature that has never been attained before, and to abandon what has already been attained.
Because it has already been attained.
This is called the essence and characteristics of the truth of accumulation.
What is the truth of cessation?

It is the truth of cessation distinguished by means of characteristics, profundity, convention, ultimate meaning, incompleteness, completeness, lack of adornment, possession of adornment, remainder, no remainder, supremacy, and distinctions.

As for characteristics, it refers to the non-arising of afflictions in true suchness and the noble path, whether it is the basis of cessation, the agent of cessation, or the nature of cessation, these are the characteristics of the truth of cessation.
As the World-Honored One said:
The eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind, in this place, name and form completely cease without remainder.
It is also said:

Therefore, you should now contemplate this place, namely, where the eye ultimately ceases and is far removed from the perception of form, up to where the mind ultimately ceases and is far removed from the perception of dharmas.
By this principle, it is shown that the characteristic of the truth of cessation is the cessation of contaminated dharmas in the existence of the true suchness of the object.
Profound means the ultimate quiescence of those conditioned forces.

In this way, this quiescence is neither said to be different from, nor not different from, those conditioned forces, nor both different and not different from, nor neither different nor not different from them.
Why is this?

If the ultimate quiescence of those conditioned forces were such that this quiescence could be said to be different from those conditioned forces, then it would not be related to those conditioned forces and would be a separate entity.
If it were not different, then it would be the characteristic of defilement.
For this reason, it is neither both nor neither.
Why is this?
Because it is free from conceptual proliferation.
If one gives rise to conceptual proliferation regarding this meaning, it is not right thought, not the path, not suchness, and also not skillful means of thought.
As the World-Honored One said:
The exhaustion, separation, desirelessness, cessation, tranquility, and disappearance of these six sense bases, etc.

If one says there is difference, non-difference, both difference and non-difference, or neither difference nor non-difference, one gives rise to conceptual proliferation where there is no conceptual proliferation.
As long as there are six sense bases, there can be conceptual proliferation;
When the six sense bases cease, all conceptual proliferation ceases, which is nirvana.
If one does not rightly think about such cessation of conceptual proliferation and tranquil nirvana, this is called conceptual proliferation, because one thinks differently from how one should think.
How should one think differently?
It means to think in various ways, such as about the correct, wonderful, and detached.
The conventional refers to the cessation attained by subduing the seeds through the worldly path. Therefore, the World-Honored One separately calls it a part of nirvana.
The ultimate is that cessation which is attained by the noble wisdom that forever uproots the seeds.
The incomplete is that cessation which is possessed by those still in training, whether included in the fruit of stream-entry, once-returning, or non-returning.
The complete is that cessation which is possessed by those no longer in training, included in the fruit of arhatship.
The unadorned is that cessation which is possessed by the arhat liberated by wisdom, because it is not adorned with the most excellent qualities such as the three clear knowledges.

The adorned is that cessation which is possessed by the arhat liberated in both ways, who has the three clear knowledges and the six supernormal powers, because it is adorned with innumerable kinds of most excellent qualities.
That with remainder is that cessation which has remaining elements.
That without remainder is that cessation which has no remaining elements.
The most excellent is that cessation which is included in the nirvÄá¹‡a with no fixed abode of buddhas and bodhisattvas, because they always abide in the benefit and happiness of all sentient beings.
The distinctions are called without remainder, permanently severed, permanently emerged, permanently emitted, exhaustion, separation from desire, cessation, calmness, submergence, and so forth.
Why is it called without remainder?
Because of the remaining phrases.
Without remainder is the main phrase, and the rest are explanatory phrases. Therefore, it is said that because of the remaining phrases, this is explained by the subsequent specific phrases.
Because both the entanglements and the latent tendencies are completely severed, it is called without remainder.
Why is it called permanently emerged?
Because it is permanently emerged from the entanglements.
This is said based on severing the entanglements, meaning that those that have already arisen are all completely abandoned.
Why is it called permanently emitted?
Because it is permanently emitted from the latent tendencies.
This is said based on severing the latent tendencies, meaning that except for the root, they are forever unarisen.
Thus, these cessations are established as two kinds due to the distinction of the paths of seeing and cultivation, and because of exhaustion and separation from desire.
Next, it is asked: Why is it called exhaustion?
Because the path of insight is the antidote that causes one to be free from the bonds of the passions.
The remaining part of the aggregate of passions is also called extinction.
Why is it called separation from desire?
Because the path of cultivation is the antidote that causes one to be free from the bonds of the passions.
Because the path of cultivation is the gradual manifestation of separation from desire for the various stages, it is called separation from desire.
Because of this separation from the bonds, future suffering is extinguished.
Next, the text asks, Why is it called extinction?
Because future suffering, its result, is not produced, it is able to bring about the state of future nonproduction of suffering, and for that reason it is called extinction.
Also, in this present life, sorrow and distress are quieted.
Next, the text asks, Why is it called quiescence?
Because in this present life, the suffering of the mind that has that as a result is forever inactive.
Why is it called submergence?
Because the remaining events are forever extinguished and submerged.
The aggregates that are attracted by past karma and the passions naturally come to an end, and for that reason it is called submergence.
Because of these different phrases, the previous general phrase, extinction without remainder, is explained.
Why is this cessation also called unconditioned?
Because it is free from the three characteristics.
It is ultimately contrary to the three characteristics of conditioned phenomena: arising, ceasing, and abiding and changing, thus it is called unconditioned.
Why is this cessation also called difficult to see?
Because it transcends the realm of the physical eye and the divine eye.
It is only the realm of activity of the eye of holy wisdom, thus it is called difficult to see.
Why is this cessation also called non-turning?
Because it is permanently free from the turning of the various destinies.
It is eternally abiding, free from the turning and coming and going of the various destinies such as hell, thus it is called non-turning.
Why is this cessation called not lowly?
Because it is free from the three cravings.
It is permanently free from the three cravings of desire, form, and formlessness, and is not lowly in any existence, thus it is called not lowly.
Why is this cessation also called nectar?
Because it is free from the demon of the aggregates.
It is permanently free from the aggregates that are the basis of all death, thus it is called nectar.
Why is this cessation also called uncontaminated?
Because one is forever separated from all afflictions and the demon of death.
Why is this cessation also called a dwelling place?
Because it is the basis for the bliss of being free from wrongdoing.
Because it is the basis for the bliss of liberation, it is called a dwelling place.
Why is this cessation also called an island?
Because it is cut off from the three realms.
Because it rises up as a high plain in the great ocean of birth and death, it is likened to an island.
Why is this cessation also called a great refuge?
Because it can prevent all great sufferings and calamities.
Because one who has attained this cessation is forever separated from the calamities of suffering such as birth, old age, sickness, etc.
Why is this cessation also called a refuge?
Because it is the basis for the skillful means of non-deceptive intention.
Because the intention and correct skillful means that arise towards that cessation are the basis for the non-deceptive nature.
The meaning of being the basis is the meaning of refuge.
Why is this cessation called the supreme refuge?
Because it is the basis for the supreme holy nature of all refuges.
Because this cessation is the basis of the supreme holy nature that is the refuge and the object of the expedient means by which arhats attain it.
Why is this cessation also called immortal?
Because it is eternally free from birth.
Because those who are free from birth are necessarily free from death.
Why is this cessation called free from heat?
Because it is eternally free from the heat of all passions.
Because it is eternally free from the great heat of the suffering of not obtaining what one desires.
Why is this cessation called free from burning?
Because it is eternally free from all the afflictions of sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
Because all the burning of sorrow, etc., is eternally extinguished and extremely cool, it is called free from burning.
Why is this cessation also called peaceful?
Because it is the basis of the abode of fearlessness.
Because it is the basis of the holy abode, free from all fears of old age, sickness, death, etc., it is called peaceful.
Why is this cessation also called cool?
Because it is the basis of all beneficial matters.
Because it is the support for all pure and cool wholesome dharmas, it is called cool.
Why is this cessation also called a pleasant state?
Because it is the state of ultimate bliss.
Because it is the basis for supramundane bliss, it is called a pleasant state.
Why is this cessation called leading to auspiciousness?
Because it is the basis for attaining that easy practice, and because it is the object of easy practice for attaining nirvana.
Why is this cessation also called free from illness?
Because it is forever free from all obstructive illnesses.
Because it is free from the illnesses of afflictions and other obstructions, it is called free from illness.
Why is this cessation also called unmoving?
Because it is forever free from all distraction and agitation.
Because it is free from the distraction and agitation of conceptual proliferation regarding various objects, it is called unmoving.
Why is this cessation also called nirvana?
Because it is the basis for the abode of signlessness, quiescence, and great bliss.
It is the ultimate cessation of all conceptual thoughts of form and so forth, and the abode of great peace and bliss that is the object of that [cessation].
Next, based on the truth of cessation, the distinctions in the meanings of non-arising and so forth are explained. Because they are contrary to the characteristics of the truth of suffering.
The characteristic of the truth of suffering is the continuous arising among the various classes of sentient beings.
In order to reverse that characteristic, therefore it is asked:
Why is this cessation also called non-arising?
Because it is free from continuity.
The characteristic of the truth of suffering is that after continuous arising, the various parts of one's own body gradually become complete.
In order to reverse that characteristic, therefore it is asked:
Why is this cessation also called non-arising?
Because it is forever free from subsequent gradual arising.
The characteristic of the truth of suffering is created by the power of past karma and afflictions.
In order to reverse that characteristic, therefore it is asked:
Why is this cessation also called non-creation?
Because it is forever free from the power that attracts future karma and afflictions.
Moreover, present suffering is the basis for creating other karmic afflictions with different karmic retributions.
In order to reverse those characteristics, therefore it is asked:
Why is this cessation also called non-action?
Because it does not serve as a basis for creating present karmic afflictions.
Moreover, the characteristic of suffering is the uninterrupted continuation of karmic retributions in future existences.
In order to reverse that characteristic, therefore it is asked:
Why is this cessation also called non-arising?
Because it is permanently free from the continuation of birth in the future.

Furthermore, the truth of cessation has four kinds of characteristics, namely the characteristic of cessation, the characteristic of tranquility, the characteristic of sublimity, and the characteristic of separation.
Why is it called the characteristic of cessation?
Because it is free from the bonds of afflictions.
That is to say, because it is free from the bonds of afflictions, which are the causes of saá¹ƒsÄra, it is called cessation.
Why is it called the characteristic of tranquility?
Because it is free from suffering.
Because it is free from the aggregates that are grasped, which have the characteristic of non-tranquility and are included in the suffering of conditioned existence, it is called tranquility.
Why is it called the characteristic of sublimity?
Because it is the object of delight and purity.
The ultimate separation from afflictions and suffering, naturally delighting and purifying as its essence, is called wonderful.
Why is it called characterized by separation?
Because it always benefits.
No longer retreating, supremely peaceful, benefiting as it does in sequence, is called always benefiting.
Peaceful benefit is the supreme good nature, which is the characteristic of the truth of cessation.
What is the truth of the path?
It is that by which one knows suffering, severs the accumulation, realizes cessation, and cultivates the path. This is the general characteristic of the truth of the path.
Herein, the essence of the path is revealed by its function in relation to the four noble truths.
Moreover, the path is of five kinds: the path of provisions, the path of preparation, the path of seeing, the path of cultivation, and the ultimate path.
These five kinds are revealed by the essence of the path itself and its retinue, thereby distinguishing the truth of the path.

The path of equipment refers to the morality possessed by ordinary beings, guarding the sense-doors, knowing moderation in food and drink, never sleeping in the first or last watches of the night, diligently cultivating calming and contemplation, and abiding in right knowledge.

Furthermore, there are other practices of various wholesome dharmas, such as the wisdom born of hearing, thinking, and cultivation. By cultivating these, one attains the nature of a vessel for realizing liberation.

That is to say, the morality possessed by ordinary beings, up to abiding in right knowledge, etc., is the essence of the path of equipment. Because by cultivating pure morality, etc., to the utmost, it is perfected.

Furthermore, there are other practices of various wholesome dharmas refers to non-remorsefulness, etc. The wisdom born of hearing, thinking, etc., attains the stage of heat, etc., and in sequence sees the truths, permanently severing the obstructions and attaining the nature of a continuous vessel.
The path of preparation refers to all the equipment that is a preparation.
